maml:description.maml:para: Disables a binding to a network adapter.

The Disable-NetAdapterBinding cmdlet disables a binding to a network adapter. Running this cmdlet causes loss of network connectivity depending on the binding that is disabled. Disabling some adapter bindings can automatically enable other network adapter bindings.
Specifies an array of network adapter names.

Indicates that this cmdlet disables all protocols and filters associated with this network adapter that can be disabled. Some protocols and filters may be mandatory and therefore cannot be disabled. Disabling some network adapter bindings can cause other network adapter bindings to automatically be enabled. Each network adapter binding is disabled only once so after running with this parameter there may still be network adapter bindings that are enabled.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the `*-Job` cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113372)cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251).

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the underlying name of the transport or filter in the following form.
- `ms_xxxx`, such as `ms_tcpip`.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies the transport or filter name shown in the Networking tab under the network adapter properties in Windows Server® 2012 and later.

Indicates that the cmdlet includes both visible and hidden network adapters in the operation. If a wildcard character is used to identify a network adapter, then the wildcard character is matched against both hidden and visible adapters.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Indicates that this cmdlet disables all protocols and filters associated with this network adapter that can be disabled. Some protocols and filters may be mandatory and therefore cannot be disabled. Disabling some network adapter bindings can cause other network adapter bindings to automatically be enabled. Each network adapter binding is disabled only once so after running with this parameter there may still be network adapter bindings that are enabled.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the `*-Job` cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113372)cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251).

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the underlying name of the transport or filter in the following form.
- `ms_xxxx`, such as `ms_tcpip`.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies the transport or filter name shown in the Networking tab under the network adapter properties in Windows Server® 2012 and later.

Indicates that the cmdlet includes both visible and hidden network adapters in the operation. If a wildcard character is used to identify a network adapter, then the wildcard character is matched against both hidden and visible adapters.

Specifies an array of network adapter interface descriptions. For a physical network adapter this is typically the name of the vendor of the network adapter followed by a part number and description, such as `Contoso 12345 Gigabit Network Device`.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The `Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance` object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (`#`) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

The `Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance` object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (`#`) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Disable TCP/IPv4 on a network adapter then restart it

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command disables TCP/IPv4 on the network adapter named MyAdapter using the display name Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4) and restarts the network adapter.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Disable TCP/IPv4 on a specific adapter using a component ID

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command disables TCP/IPv4 on the network adapter named MyAdapter using the component ID ms_tcpip and restarts the network adapter.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Disable TCP/IPv4 on a specified adapter using a wildcard character

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command disables TCP/IPv4 on network adapter named MyAdapter using a wildcard character in the display name and restarts the network adapter.

maml:description.maml:para: Enables binding of a protocol or filter to a network adapter.

The Enable-NetAdapterBinding cmdlet enables binding of a protocol or filter to the network. By default this cmdlet operates on the protocols and filters visible in the Windows UI Network Adapter properties pages. Enabling some adapter bindings can automatically disable other network adapter bindings.
Specifies an array of network adapter names.

Indicates that the cmdlet enables all protocols and filters associated with this network adapter. Enabling certain network adapter bindings can automatically disable other network adapter bindings. Each network adapter binding is only enabled once. Therefore, after running the cmdlet with this parameter specified there may still be network adapter bindings that are disabled.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the `*-Job` cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113372)cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251).

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies an array of underlying names of the transport or filter in the following form. - `ms_xxxx`, such as `ms_tcpip`.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies an array of transport or filter name shown in the Networking tab under the network adapter properties in Windows Server® 2012 and later.

Indicates that the cmdlet includes both visible and hidden network adapters in the operation. By default only visible network adapters are included. If a wildcard character is used in identifying a network adapter and this parameter has been specified, then the wildcard string is matched against both hidden and visible network adapters.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Indicates that the cmdlet enables all protocols and filters associated with this network adapter. Enabling certain network adapter bindings can automatically disable other network adapter bindings. Each network adapter binding is only enabled once. Therefore, after running the cmdlet with this parameter specified there may still be network adapter bindings that are disabled.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251).

Specifies an array of network adapter interface descriptions. For a physical network adapter this is the name of the vendor of the network adapter followed by a part number and description, such as `12345 Gigabit Network Device`.

command:example.maml:title: - Example 1: Enable TCP/IPv4 on the specified network adapter -
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> Enable-NetAdapterBinding -Name "MyAdapter" -DisplayName "Internet Protocol Version 4 (TCP/IPv4)"
This command is a version of the cmdlet that enables TCPv4 and IPv4 on the network adapter named MyAdapter using wildcard characters in the display name and restarts the network adapter. PS C:\> Enable-NetAdapterBinding -Name "MyAdapter" -DisplayName "Inter* (TCP/IPv4)"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command enables TCPv4 and IPv4 on the network adapter named MyAdapter using the display name and restarts the network adapter.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Enable TCP/IPv4 on the specified network adapter using a component ID

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command enables TCPv4 and IPv4 on the network adapter named MyAdapter using the component ID and restarts the network adapter.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets a list of bindings for a network adapter.

The Get-NetAdapterBinding cmdlet gets a list of bindings for a network adapter. By default only the visible bindings shown in the Networking tab under the Network Adapter properties in Windows UI is returned. To get all properties for a network adapter, use the AllProperties parameter.
Indicates that the cmdlet gets all the bindings for the network adapter.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the `*-Job` cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113372)cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251).

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies an array of underlying names of the transport or filter in the following form: `ms_xxxx`, such as `ms_tcpip`.
Specifies an array of transport or filter names shown in the Networking tab under the network adapter properties in Windows Server® 2012 and later.

Indicates that the cmdlet includes both visible and hidden network adapters in the operation. By default only visible network adapters are included. If a wildcard character is used in identifying a network adapter and this parameter has been specified, then the wildcard string is matched against both hidden and visible network adapters.

Specifies the network adapter interface description. For a physical network adapter this is typically the name of the vendor of the network adapter followed by a part number and description, such as `Contoso 12345 Gigabit Network Device`.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies an array of network adapter names.
Indicates that the cmdlet gets all the bindings for the network adapter.

For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251).

command:example.maml:title: -- Example 1: Get bindings for the specified network adapter --

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the bindings for the network adapter named MyAdapter.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Get all of the binding for the specified network adapter in an unformatted list

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all of the bindings for the network adapter named MyAdapter as an unformatted list .

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Get the state of TCP/IPv4 on the specified network adapter using the display name

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the state of the TCP/IPv4 on the network adapter named MyAdapter using display name.

command:example.maml:title: Example 4: Get the state of the TCP/IPv4 transport on the specified network adapter

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the state of the TCP/IPv4 transport on MyAdapter using component ID.

command:example.maml:title: Example 5: Get the state of TCP/IPv4 and TCP/IPv6 on all visible network adapters using a search string

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets the state of TCP/IPv4 and TCP/IPv6 on all visible network adapters using wildcard characters.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the binding state of a transport or filter on a network adapter.

The Set-NetAdapterBinding cmdlet sets the binding state of a transport or filter on a network adapter. By default only visible bindings are set unless the AllBindings parameter is specified. If only enabling or disabling bindings, then the Enable-NetAdapterBinding or Disable-NetAdapterBinding cmdlets can be used. If you disable or enable a network adapter binding, the cmdlet can automatically enable or disable other network adapter bindings.
Specifies an array of network adapter names.
Indicates that the cmdlet sets filters or transports that are not visible by default.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the `*-Job` cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113372)cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251).

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies as an array the underlying names of the transport or filter in the following form: `ms_xxxx`, such as `ms_tcpip`.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies an array of transport or filter names shown in the Networking tab under the network adapter properties in Windows Server® 2012 and later.
Indicates whether the transport or filter is enabled or disabled. The acceptable values for this parameter are: $True or $False.

Indicates that the cmdlet includes both visible and hidden network adapters in the operation. By default only visible network adapters are included. If a wildcard character is used in identifying a network adapter and this parameter has been specified, then the wildcard string is matched against both hidden and visible network adapters.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Indicates that the cmdlet sets filters or transports that are not visible by default.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the `*-Job` cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113372)cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251).

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227967) or [Get-CimSession](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?LinkId=227966)cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies as an array the underlying names of the transport or filter in the following form: `ms_xxxx`, such as `ms_tcpip`.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies an array of transport or filter names shown in the Networking tab under the network adapter properties in Windows Server® 2012 and later.
Indicates whether the transport or filter is enabled or disabled. The acceptable values for this parameter are: $True or $False.

Indicates that the cmdlet includes both visible and hidden network adapters in the operation. By default only visible network adapters are included. If a wildcard character is used in identifying a network adapter and this parameter has been specified, then the wildcard string is matched against both hidden and visible network adapters.

Specifies an array of network adapter interface descriptions. For a physical network adapter this is typically the name of the vendor of the network adapter followed by a part number and description, such as `Contoso 12345 Gigabit Network Device`.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

To manage the job, use the `*-Job` cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113372)cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=113251).

The default is the current session on the local computer.

The default is the current session on the local computer.

Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Specifies an array of transport or filter names shown in the Networking tab under the network adapter properties in Windows Server® 2012 and later.
Indicates whether the transport or filter is enabled or disabled. The acceptable values for this parameter are: $True or $False.

Indicates that the cmdlet includes both visible and hidden network adapters in the operation. By default only visible network adapters are included. If a wildcard character is used in identifying a network adapter and this parameter has been specified, then the wildcard string is matched against both hidden and visible network adapters.

Specifies an array of network adapter names.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of `0` is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

The `Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance` object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (`#`) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

The `Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimInstance` object is a wrapper class that displays Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) objects. The path after the pound sign (`#`) provides the namespace and class name for the underlying WMI object.

command:example.maml:title: - Example 1: Enable TCP/IPv4 on the specified network adapter -

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command enables TCP/IPv4 on the network adapter named MyAdapter.

command:example.maml:title: - Example 2: Disable TCP/IPv4 on the specified network adapter -

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command disables TCP/IPv4 on the network adapter named MyAdapter.

command:example.maml:title: Example 3: Enable TCP/IPv4 on the specified network adapter using the component ID

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command enables TCP/IPv4 on the network adapter named MyAdapter using the component ID.
